issue.message: Not targeting the latest versions of Android; compatibility modes apply. Consider testing and updating this version. Consult the `android.os.Build.VERSION_CODES` javadoc for details.
issue.summary: Target SDK attribute is not targeting latest version
issue.explanation:
When your application runs on a version of Android that is more recent than your `targetSdkVersion` specifies that it has been tested with, various compatibility modes kick in. This ensures that your application continues to work, but it may look out of place. For example, if the `targetSdkVersion` is less than 14, your app may get an option button in the UI.
To fix this issue, set the `targetSdkVersion` to the highest available value. Then test your app to make sure everything works correctly. You may want to consult the compatibility notes to see what changes apply to each version you are adding support for: http://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Build.VERSION_CODES.html

issue.summary: Target SDK attribute is not targeting latest version
issue.explanation:
When your application runs on a version of Android that is more recent than your `targetSdkVersion` specifies that it has been tested with, various compatibility modes kick in. This ensures that your application continues to work, but it may look out of place. For example, if the `targetSdkVersion` is less than 14, your app may get an option button in the UI.
To fix this issue, set the `targetSdkVersion` to the highest available value. Then test your app to make sure everything works correctly. You may want to consult the compatibility notes to see what changes apply to each version you are adding support for: http://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Build.VERSION_CODES.html

issue.message: A newer version of com.android.support:appcompat-v7 than 21.0.3 is available: 22.2.0
issue.explanation: This detector looks for usages of libraries where the version you are using is not the current stable release. Using older versions is fine, and there are cases where you deliberately want to stick with an older version. However, you may simply not be aware that a more recent version is available, and that is what this lint check helps find.

issue.message: This `versionCode` value (`1`) is not used; it is always overridden by the value specified in the Gradle build script (`1`)
issue.summary: Value overridden by Gradle build script
issue.explanation: The value of (for example) `minSdkVersion` is only used if it is not specified in the `build.gradle` build scripts. When specified in the Gradle build scripts, the manifest value is ignored and can be misleading, so should be removed to avoid ambiguity.

issue.message: This `versionName` value (`1.0`) is not used; it is always overridden by the value specified in the Gradle build script (`1.0`)
issue.summary: Value overridden by Gradle build script
issue.explanation: The value of (for example) `minSdkVersion` is only used if it is not specified in the `build.gradle` build scripts. When specified in the Gradle build scripts, the manifest value is ignored and can be misleading, so should be removed to avoid ambiguity.

issue.message: This `minSdkVersion` value (`8`) is not used; it is always overridden by the value specified in the Gradle build script (`8`)
issue.summary: Value overridden by Gradle build script
issue.explanation: The value of (for example) `minSdkVersion` is only used if it is not specified in the `build.gradle` build scripts. When specified in the Gradle build scripts, the manifest value is ignored and can be misleading, so should be removed to avoid ambiguity.

issue.message: This `targetSdkVersion` value (`21`) is not used; it is always overridden by the value specified in the Gradle build script (`21`)
issue.summary: Value overridden by Gradle build script
issue.explanation: The value of (for example) `minSdkVersion` is only used if it is not specified in the `build.gradle` build scripts. When specified in the Gradle build scripts, the manifest value is ignored and can be misleading, so should be removed to avoid ambiguity.

issue.message: This `MotionEvent` should be recycled after use with `#recycle()`
issue.explanation: Many resources, such as TypedArrays, VelocityTrackers, etc., should be recycled (with a `recycle()` call) after use. This lint check looks for missing `recycle()` calls.

issue.message: Missing density variation folders in `res`: drawable-xxhdpi, drawable-xxxhdpi
issue.explanation: Icons will look best if a custom version is provided for each of the major screen density classes (low, medium, high, extra-high, extra-extra-high). This lint check identifies folders which are missing, such as `drawable-hdpi`. Low density is not really used much anymore, so this check ignores the ldpi density. To force lint to include it, set the environment variable `ANDROID_LINT_INCLUDE_LDPI=true`. For more information on current density usage, see http://developer.android.com/resources/dashboard/screens.html

issue.message: Custom view `SwipeMenuView` is missing constructor used by tools: `(Context)` or `(Context,AttributeSet)` or `(Context,AttributeSet,int)`
issue.summary: Missing View constructors for XML inflation
issue.explanation:
Some layout tools (such as the Android layout editor for Studio & Eclipse) needs to find a constructor with one of the following signatures: * `View(Context context)` * `View(Context context, AttributeSet attrs)` * `View(Context context, AttributeSet attrs, int defStyle)`
If your custom view needs to perform initialization which does not apply when used in a layout editor, you can surround the given code with a check to see if `View#isInEditMode()` is false, since that method will return `false` at runtime but true within a user interface editor.
issue.errorLine1: public class SwipeMenuView extends LinearLayout implements OnClickListener {
